questions.clue: This biome is characterized by low rainfall and high temperatures, often found in regions like the Sahara.
Known for its dense canopy, this biome has the highest biodiversity of all terrestrial biomes.
Covering large parts of Canada and Russia, this biome is defined by coniferous forests and cold climates.
This biome, also called a steppe, is characterized by vast open spaces with grasslands and few trees.
Found near the poles, this biome features permafrost and minimal vegetation, primarily mosses and lichens.
In Greek mythology, he is the king of the gods and ruler of Mount Olympus.
This Norse god is known for his mischievous nature and is the brother of Thor.
In Hindu mythology, this deity is known as the preserver and protector of the universe.
This Egyptian goddess is known as the goddess of motherhood, magic, and fertility.
In Aztec mythology, this feathered serpent deity is associated with wind and knowledge.
This invention by James Watt greatly improved the efficiency of steam engines in the late 18th century.
Invented by Eli Whitney in 1793, this device revolutionized the cotton industry by quickly separating seeds from fibers.
This innovation by Henry Bessemer in the 1850s allowed for the mass production of steel.
Developed by Samuel Morse in the 1830s, this communication system used dots and dashes to transmit messages over wires.
This revolutionary textile machine invented by John Kay in 1733 allowed a single weaver to weave much wider fabrics.
This 1959 album by Miles Davis is often cited as the best-selling jazz album of all time.
Released in 1964, this John Coltrane album opens with the track "Acknowledgement."
Herbie Hancock's 1965 album is known for its fusion of jazz and electronic music, featuring tracks like "Maiden Voyage."
This 1956 album by Duke Ellington and his orchestra features the famous suite "The Far East Suite."
Recorded in 1959, this Charles Mingus album includes the politically charged track "Fables of Faubus."
This paradox, named after a Greek philosopher, involves a runner never reaching a finish line because they must always cover half the remaining distance.
Hilbert's paradox involves a hotel with an infinite number of rooms; even when full, it can still accommodate more guests.
This paradox of self-reference is illustrated by the statement, 'This sentence is false.'
Named after a British philosopher, this paradox involves a set of all sets that do not contain themselves.
This paradox, introduced by Banach and Tarski in 1924, suggests that a sphere can be split into a finite number of pieces and reassembled into two identical spheres.

final.clue: Published in 1924, this novel by Hermann Hesse features a protagonist whose journey blends Eastern spirituality with Western culture.
